questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the hospital by his wife with complaints of persistent low mood, reduced interest in most activities, episodes of crying in the night, reduced sleep, excessive guilt, and self-doubt. There is a history of attempting to commit suicide 2 times. The patient was admitted and started with antidepressants. The patient is at higher risk for

options.label: C
options.text: Progressing to mania in the coming week

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Committing suicide About 10 to 15 percent of all depressed patients commit suicide , and about two-thirds have suicidal ideation .

Highyeild:

Those recently hospitalized with a suicide attempt or suicidal ideation have a higher lifetime risk of successful suicide than those never hospitalized for suicidal ideation. It is usually clinically unwise to give a depressed patient a large prescription for a large number of antidepressants, especially tricyclic drugs, at the time of their discharge from the hospital. Similarly, drugs that may be activating, such as fluoxetine, may be prescribed in such a way that the energizing qualities are minimized (e.g., be given a benzodiazepine at the same time).

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Relapse of treatment can be understood only after a few weeks of treatment . Relapse cannot be known at the start of treatment with a drug. Option: C. The treatment if not monitored and prolonged can lead to mania but not an immediate effect(within a few weeks) of treatment of patients with depression.

questions.text: A 25-year-old single male known case of bipolar disorder, the most recent episode of depression. He began smoking marijuana, almost daily. After one night of excessive marijuana smoking, he was hearing voices and reported that he “could not take it anymore” and was contemplating suicide. He admits that he had attempted suicide by overdose three weeks prior. Which of the following puts this patient at the greatest risk of death by suicide?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Past suicide attempt All of the options given increase his risk of attempting and completing the act of suicide . However, the most potent predictor of future behavior is past behavior.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Options A, and D – Psychiatric illnesses, major depression, anxiety and psychotic disorders do increase the risk of suicide. However, a past suicide attempt is the most consistent indicator of future attempts. Option B – Males complete suicide more often than females. There is a bimodal distribution concerning age, with one peak in early adulthood, and the other in the elderly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has just been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Although she never attempted suicide, she acknowledges that she thought she would probably jump off a local bridge if she ever had the chance. She denies any history of excessively elevated moods. You decide to start her on antidepressant therapy. Two weeks later, this patient is at the greatest risk for?

options.label: C
options.text: Medication non-compliance to medication and recurrence of sadness of mood

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suicide completion When antidepressant medications first begin to work , patients tend to report an increase in energy levels before significant improvement in mood symptoms . For this reason, carrying out suicide plans is more of a risk during this period.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - Extrapyramidal symptoms are a consequence of typical antipsychotic use, not antidepressant use. Option B - This patient has nothing in her history to indicate bipolar disorder as a more appropriate diagnosis; therefore, there is no reason to believe manic episodes will be precipitated by antidepressant use. Option C - Medication non-compliance with effective psychopharmacological treatments during both acute and maintenance therapy is a major cause of morbidity among patients with schizophrenia and disorders with poor insight, not among patients with depression. Although noncompliance is a possibility with any patient, it is not the best choice listed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male diagnosed with the major depressive disorder was brought to the emergency room following a suicide attempt. He attempted suicide 3 weeks prior too. Which of the following antidepressants would not be the best choice for a patient with a history of suicidal ideation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Imipramine In considering antidepressant use in suicidal or impulsive patients , caution should be taken in using medications that may be lethal in overdose (e.g., tricyclic antidepressants like imipramine) or that may exacerbate disinhibition or cognitive deficits (e.g., benzodiazepines). Therefore, it is not the best idea to prescribe a TCA to this patient.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A - Bupropion can be used alone or in combination with another medication. Options B, and C - Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) are better choices.

questions.text: The highest suicide rates are in which of the following age groups?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Older than age 65 years Suicide is almost twice as frequent in older adults as in the general population . The suicide rate for white men older than 65 years of age is five times higher than that of the general population.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – Suicide rates are lower in those between 15 and 24 years of age as compared to elderly individuals. Options B and C - Suicide rates are rising most rapidly in young adults, but the greatest risk remains in those people older than the age of 65 years.

questions.text: A suicidal patient with chronic depressive disorder presents very frustrated and in tears. He tells you he cannot stop thinking about ending his life. On asking for a plan, he gave details where he could buy a handgun and where he would go to shoot himself. He has not had adequate control of his symptoms since his last antidepressant change 1 month ago. You advised hospitalization, but the patient refuses. Your next step in the management would be:

options.label: A
options.text: Admit the patient to the hospital anyway.

options.label: B
options.text: Give the latest antidepressant more time to take its effect.

options.label: C
options.text: Change to another class of antidepressant and manage on a partial hospital program.

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate psychotherapy to discuss the reasons behind the suicidal thoughts.

questions.correct_answer: A. Admit the patient to the hospital anyway.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Admit the patient to the hospital anyway. Inpatient treatment is required for suicidal patients with intent and specific plans believed to be too much at risk for outpatient therapy or partial hospital programs. Such hospitalization is preferably on a voluntary basis, but if the patient refuses, involuntary admission is required. Patients can be admitted to the hospital against their will if they are a danger to themselves or to other people .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Options B, and C - The options of changing antidepressants and giving more time for the medication to take effect are not the best options in this circumstance, although they may be in patients when suicide is less of an acute risk. Option D - Psychotherapy is also not an option when immediate intervention is needed with actively suicidal patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady has been diagnosed to be suffering from major depression. However, for the past 4 days, she has been expressing suicidal ideas. In addition, she was also found writing a suicide note. The best line of management, in this case, would be?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the dose of antidepressants and asking relatives to take a close view of the patient.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Admit and consider ECT The best line of management, in this case, is to admit the patient to the psychiatry unit and evaluate her for ECT to mitigate the risk of suicide.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – Increasing the dose of antidepressants when a patient is acutely suicidal is not indicated. Option B – Psychotherapy, especially supportive psychotherapy is one of the modalities of treatment for depression along with pharmacotherapy. However, it is indicated in the long run but not in an acutely suicidal patient. Option C – Antipsychotics are indicated for the management of depression with psychotic symptoms.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man, living alone, following the death of his wife 2 months ago was taken to the psychiatrist for evaluation of his depressed mood. He also reports decreased energy and concentration, and loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities. Although he never attempted suicide, he stated that he is “better off dead.” All of the following factors are associated with high suicide risk EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Age less than 45 Suicide is almost twice as frequent in older adults as in the general population . Suicide is more common among those aged 65 and above.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – It has been shown that women make more suicidal gestures , but men are more likely to choose lethal methods and thus are more likely to successfully commit suicide. Therefore, the male gender is considered more of a risk factor for suicide completion. Option B – Depression has been observed to be the most common cause of suicide worldwide. Option D – Social isolation, lack of social support, unemployment, and recent divorce are all other risk factors for suicide.

questions.text: As a physician in charge of an ICU where a patient is recovering from a suicidal attempt, the most important step for further management would be interviewing the patient for?

options.label: A
options.text: Reason for suicide attempt and his current mood

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Persisting suicidal ideation Persisting suicidal ideation after recovering from a suicidal attempt is one of the tangible signs that the patient would further try to attempt suicide. So it becomes mandatory to interview for persisting suicidal ideation in a patient recovering from a suicidal attempt.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Options A, B – Enquiring the reasons for the current attempt to suicide and the method used is also of vital importance to assess the further risk of suicide. However, interviewing for persisting suicidal ideation takes precedence. Option D – Family history of suicide is an important risk factor for suicide. However, it doesn’t determine the further risk of suicide in a patient recovering from suicide.

questions.text: Who among the following patients is at the HIGHEST risk for suicide?

options.label: A
options.text: A 24-year-old woman who is successfully being treated for depression

options.label: B
options.text: A 29-year-old man who was recently demoted from his job.

options.label: C
options.text: A 33-year-old man regularly consumes alcohol and purchased a gun

options.label: D
options.text: A 45-year-old woman who recently found out her cancer is in full remission

questions.correct_answer: C. A 33-year-old man regularly consumes alcohol and purchased a gun
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A 33-year-old man regularly consumes alcohol and purchased a gun A 33-year-old man who regularly consumes alcohol and purchased a gun is at the highest risk for suicide. Alcohol use disorder has been observed to be a frequent cause of suicide .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Options A, D - A 24-year-old woman whose symptoms of depression have been resolved and a 45-year-old woman who recently found out her cancer is in full remission are not at risk for suicide. Option B - A 29-year-old man who was recently demoted is at risk of going into depression and suicidal risk is also present but it's not the best option.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male has been experiencing some tough times and says he “cannot seem to get out of this hole.” since his wife asked him for a divorce eight months ago. He feels hopeless that things will improve. All he wants to do is sleep, and he skipped work today because he “just could not get out of bed.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Offer to schedule an appointment with him for later in the day

options.label: D
options.text: Refer him to a psychiatrist for further workup

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Assess for suicidality This patient’s interaction is a call for help . He paints a picture of a depressed mood, lacks motivation, and uses the word “hopeless.” So the most appropriate next step for this patient would be to assess if the man is contemplating suicide.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option B – Though this question would be of help to diagnosing depression, it is not as important as assessing suicide risk . Option C & D – Though follow-up appointments and referral to a psychiatrist may be important steps in the management of this patient, the most pressing issue is whether the patient is contemplating suicide.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with no significant past medical and psychiatric history presents with no interest in anything, a nihilistic attitude, and a sad appearance with suicidal ideas and plans. The most appropriate management for this patient is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Electroconvulsive therapy after admission. The patient is having severe depression and suicidal risk . In this case, the first choice of management is electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) and it’s always preferable to admit a patient with active suicide ideation and then give it instead of giving ECT on an outpatient basis.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A – Though antidepressants are the first-line agents for the management of depression, they are slow to work and aren’t of much use in an acutely suicidal patient. Option B - Behavior therapy can be tried along with antidepressants in the long run once the patient is not at risk for suicide. Option D- ECT is done after admission of the patient.
